40694047.review:
Каман каман - веревер ю ар!

Древняя как говно мамонта и лютая как удар кремниевым ножом под рёбра игра Blood.
Классика и главный конкурент не менее старинного Quake по степени жестокости. Что вы там говорите? Мэнхант? Постал? Не, не слышали. 

Некоторая сентиментальщина присутствует - главгерой - наемный охотник за головами Калеб пытается спасти свою возлюбленную из лап некоего сатанинского культа.

Опять же пара видеовставок присутствует - для 1997 года это очень круто. Видосы совершенно не напрягают и ни к чему не обязывают, но добавляют атмосферности в этот пи3dец.

Забавен выбор главного злодея - не какой нибудь там Сотона - а наш с вами земеля Чернобог (Tchernobog) - злобное божество древних славян. Промежуточные боссы также радуют.
И конечно множество отсылок к фильмам 80-х 90-х годов наподобии "Зловещих мертвецов", "Сияния" и тд.

Игра доставляет своей мракобесной атмосферой - немалую роль в которой играет загробный саундтрек.
Наверное игра бы не зацепила, не будь у нее этих похоронных мелодий.
Музыкальные темы Ubholy Voices и Fate Of The Damned  - просто таки шедевры. Музыка присутствует в формате аудиозаписи - а также в старинном миди-формате - для встроенного в компьютер звукового синтезатора. И так сразу трудно сказать, какой вариант слушается круче.
Вобщем на мой взгляд - один из лучших игровых саундтреков всех времен.
 
У игры есть прямой духовный последователь - Painkiller - который лично я не особо жалую за нудность, тоскливость геймплея и длинные 3аёbывающие видеовставки - там и не пахнет трешем, угаром и черным юмором Blood. 
Наиболее близки к дедушке по духу Left 4 Dead и Zombie Army Trilogy - но только по духу, игровые процессы несколько различаются.

Короче всем кто ценит всякое старье - играть в обязательном порядке.

10 из 10

Blood: One Unit Whole Blood is very good old classic game, okay story time now.

You play as Caleb, a gunslinger who along with his lover Ophelia have risen to be the Chosen in the cult Cabal who worship the dread demon Tchernobog. But one day Tchernobog kills the four chosen for failing him, but soon years later the merciless gunfighter Caleb rises from his grave with one thought revenge.

Now what’s good about the game, the combat was very good and fun with great weapons to use like a sawed off shotgun to a tommy gun to more unique weapons like a skull on a stick called a life leech that shoots fire balls to a cannon called the Tesla cannon.

The levels were well made and gives us some unique place’s to fight from old castles to hellish city in turmoil and even on a train. There are all so some good secret levels in the game too.

The action was good; fast paced, and can be very hard. The enemies were cool and scary looking and tough too. But the best in the game were all the nods to classic horror movies, like the evil dead Friday the 13th and the like.

Now for the annoying, the game could have given us more of a story. And are some bugs like being killed by a door when it opens if you’re standing near it the right way. And the key maping is a pain just to make it how you want it.

So now that done Blood: One Unit Whole Blood is a kickass classic game with fun weapons, great and unique levels, fast paced action. And some could call backs to classic horror movies; the price is all so fair.

So if you want a good classic old school game that is like shadow warrior or Duke Nukem this is for you.

Un classique du FPS de l'époque, au même titre que Shadow Warrior ou Duke Nukem 3D, même si BLOOD n'a pas connu un succès aussi phénoménal que le Duke.
A savoir : le jeu nécessite une reconfiguration totale des options pour viser à la souris, se déplacer uniquement aux touches, et rendre praticable les raccourcis. 
Après ce passage obligatoire, le jeu n'est que du bon : nerveux, sanglant, loftcratien as fu*k. L'atmosphère est proche d'un Quake 1, avec moins de fantastique. BLOOD nous propose un mélange de gore, de sectes et leurs séides (zombies, gargouilles, mutant requin humanoïde, etc), et des armes originales dotées d'un véritable feeling bien distinct (fourche, tnt, pistolet de détresse, double shotgun, mitraillette de gangster, etc).
Bref, autant certains FPS de cette époque ont terriblement mal vieilli (Strife, Marathon, etc), autant BLOOD est toujours un plaisir à jouer. A ressortir régulièrement avec Doom, Duke Nukem 3D, et Quake.

Pero vamos, que el recuerdo de lo que fue este BLOOD 1 y su historia acojonante de venganza fue increíble para todos los que lo jugamos en aquella época...

Luego sacaron una PAUPÉRRIMA segunda parte que escupió y orinó en la cara de lo que fue este BLOOD. Menos mal que la gente sabemos para bien que solo existió este primero.

38139264.review:
I played through Blood on Lightly Broiled, Episodes 1 t/m 4, which was the first official release.

I am aware that I might be the odd one out that actually writes a 'not recommended' here, while it seems to have a bit of a fanbase. I actually beat the original game, and I honestly think it's not recommended for the vast majority of the people.

Let's start positive. Yes, there is enough content for quite a few hours of gameplay.
There are a lot of diverse levels, so you wouldn't really get bored if you get into this game.
I also take note of some very well-designed levels, especially in Episode 3. E3M1 & E3M2 are taking place in some town that seems to be a battlefield, and big bombs are deforming the level into different states, opening lots of places during gameplay. The game also takes you to a hospital, a big sluice in which letting the water level actually gives you access to some places, and lots of other distinctive and cool places.

For a 2.5D Build Engine game, it looks quite good, and you can see the amount of work that has gone into animating the enemies, drawing the textures, etcetera. The voice acting is good, the horror is good, there are tons of references towards horror culture, the music is good (although the sound balance is quite a bit off), making good atmosphere. However, I would like to remind everyone that this game came out in 1997, a year later(!) than the full 3D polygonal Quake 1. So yes, it has the best graphics for a 2.5 sprite-based FPS, but the standards were already a lot higher back then.

So what is the problem, you might ask? Basically, the gameplay. The control scheme is horrible, and I had to download some mods (thanks pcgamingwiki) to fix a lot of the stuff I encountered. But that's not the only thing that was annoying. 

Moral of the story: The balance in this game is just COMPLETELY GONE. The start of the first episode is idiotically hard because you don't get enough resources. Some levels, later on, are just waay too generous with ammo, which makes it idiotically easy to blast through. The enemies ok, but they have 0ms reaction time, which sometimes means that you will die within 2 seconds from 100hp just from some random (relatively weak) dude around the corner that had a few lucky shots. 

Then, you have the flying enemies, the Gargoyles and the stone Gargoyles, which are so glitchy that you don't even take fighting them seriously anymore. Mother Spiders are just plain boring (and have way too much HP), and the second boss was stuck and easily killable without doing any damage.

Also the weapons are completely off. Although having two fire modes on each weapon is pretty unique and fun, they are so unbalanced that the use of some weapons just feels like cheating, while others just don't seem to work at all mostly. I'm ok with the game challenging me to figure out what weapon to use where, but man, just having to take minutes to fight a hellhound with a shotgun and literally taking 0.3 seconds to kill him with a tesla gun, that's just not fun anymore. It's also not like you have to take care of ammo management because once you have a tesla gun, ammo is everywhere. Also, the random traps are fun once or twice, but come on, do I really have to suffer so many random traps where it is impossible to react properly?

This game is so unbalanced that it simply restricts gameplay. Some guns make it too easy, and the enemies are too glitchy and random to have fun fighting, and instead encourage you to save before every corner because they sometimes randomly kill you and sometimes randomly leave you completely unharmed. The supplies are very randomly placed, and I feel like the developers have just designed levels without play-testing them at all. Although the game has good atmosphere, it was graphically and technically way behind. 

So should you play this game? Only if you are both a dedicated old-school FPS-fan and a fan of the horror-genre. Generally, there is much better out there, but I have to give it a few kudos for its uniqueness.

TLDR: Probably the most detailed and animated 2.5D sprite-based FPS, good horror, cool references, good soundtrack, but the core gameplay is ill-balanced and makes the game frustrating and non-rewarding to play. Would not recommend unless you are a dedicated FPS-fan ánd horror fan.

Pero si algo marco para mi ese año, fue cuando gracias a un amigo, callo en mis manos una de esas recopilaciones de juegos piratas llamados “[url=https://yocreoqueno.com/2009/08/27/recopilatorios-piratas-de-juegos-para-pc/]CD-MIX[/url]”. Así descubrí Blood, un juego que utilizaba el motor Build de [url=http://advsys.net/ken/]Ken Silverman[/url] elevado a su enésima potencia, el mismo motor que ya habían utilizado otros juegos como Shadow Warrior, Redneck Rampage, y el mítico Duke Nukem 3D.
Blood podía parecer ya juego anticuado desde el mismo momento en el que salio al mercado, ya que compitió con juegos, como, Quake2, Unreal, Half-Life… pero Blood tenia algo que lo hacia especial, su gore exagerado, sus armas como la dinamita, un muñeco voodoo o un bote de fly que junto con un zippo se convertía en un lanzallamas improvisado pero muy efectivo. Destacar también un diseño de niveles muy bueno, una dificultad que era realmente jodida, y sus “Easter eggs” con multitud de referencias a clásicos del cine de Terror .

Blood ha día de hoy es un clásico de culto, una joya de los FPS de los 90, un juego que proporciona tanta diversión hoy como lo hizo en aquel año de 1998.

Desgraciadamente el código fuente de este juego se perdió, por lo que no pudieron salir, source ports que mejoraran el juego y lo adaptaran a sistemas modernos, como si ha ocurrido con muchos otros de sus contemporáneos. Durante estos años hubieron varios proyectos que mediante ingeniería inversa intentaban recrear el juego, otros proyectos intentaron portar el juego a los motores de Doom y al eDuke32 (source port del Duken Nukem 3D). 
Pero este año por fin ocurrió el milagro, un source port totalmente funcional (salvo por algunos pequeños errores que no afectan a la jugabilidad) logrado mediante ingeniería inversa. Este source port es el Blood GDX y realmente merece la pena usarlo para revivir este clásico.

35613445.review:
This is one of these bloody old school FPSes that I could not only tolerate, but actually enjoyed playing!

I think it has something to do with the dynamite. There's precisely the right amount of TNT action in this game: not too little to be just a thing to hoard for boss fights and not too much to become unremarkable. Gibs are wonderful! And there are a lot of places in the levels that you can blow up, leading to shortcuts and secret places. You can easily hurt yourself if you're not careful, which is nice.

I love how levels are set in lovecraftian early 19th century America populated by cultists, zombies and demented people hanging around in mundane locations such as train stations and supermarkets (still operational!) It's just magical.

Sound and music are the soul of this game. Caleb is wonderfully voiced by a talented actor as well as cultists with their fun enthusiastic mad gibberish. Music is playfully sinister, slow paced and slightly cartoonish.

The whole game has tributes to classic horror movies left right and center, but everyone and their mothers know that. You don't have to know much about those to enjoy the game.

Blood is extremely hard on anything but easiest difficulty as it feautres enemies with hitscan weapons instead of projectiles, but each difficulty has different types of enemies on same levels, so there's plenty of content to replay if you like challenge in games. 

I was using BloodGDX for better compatibility, it also slightly enhances the visuals by adding more 3d voxel items instead of 2d sprites and I highly recommend it.

Best build engine game?
Pros:

- Atmosphere. Great ambient sounds, visuals consisting of often darker tones of colors and pretty grimyand scuffed surfaces, the cult stuff. Those combine to make one helluva great atmosphere. Basically. Horror setting heavily offset by excessively unrealistic gore and silly dark humor. Put short, you're a former cultist, betrayed. You get resurrected and go on a rampage on the Cabal. 

- Soundtrack. MIDI goodness, sounds best with Timbres of Heaven.

- Challenging yet fair and fun gameplay. Weapons are fun. Even at mid difficulty there is a solid challenge, don't you dare stay in open and still when fighting the cultists. There are lots of secrets to find, keep on searching a level neurotically and trying every bookshelf, differing spot on a wall etc to find secret places with goodies. 

- Enemy AI is pretty good. Cultists randomly go prone to throw your aim off. They throw dynamite at higher difficulties, watch yourself! The Gargoyles constantly shift moving directions and move fast too when not attacking, to make them harder to hit. And what else is there.

- Gunplay is great. Thompson is so awesome to fire full auto and wipe out squads of cultists. Double barreled shotgun too is fun and nice boom it makes.

- The protagonist. An undead betrayed cultist who surely is not gonna just deal with his betrayal. A sarcastic combat loving gunslinger. Has a great selection of one liners, some which are uttered on certain points in levels and rest are said when you dynamite enemies. And then there also is the great, truly insane laughter randomly when you bomb enemies with dynamite.

- Truly excessive and over the top gore. Cultists who burn to death somehow get turned inside out. Their innards fall out and blood sprays high up and around them, and their skeleton falls down.

Cons:

- Closing doors of non mechanical kind crush you to death. And every door closes automatically. Really is a bad feature. Just what monolith.

- This release ain't necessarily best technically, although it is serviceable. I think the steam version should be updated to come with GDXBlood port as a launch option. Dosbox emulation does work well enough though.

So what are you waiting for?
Buy the game and embark on your adventure of slaying monsters and underlings of a vile cult.

You will see organs fly and blood everywhere, so be aware it's not for the squemish. The sound design is very effective, giving you chills as you hear enemies scream in agony and hear splats of violence. The sound track ties all this together with a very oninomus tone. 

The controls are just like the other build games and work well, but you may want to configure the controls a bit, as the layout can feel a little chaotic by default. Also swimming is a real pain as you have to tap c repeatedly to swim down, you can jump in water to dive quicker but it doesn't change the fact it feels a bit awkward, on the plus side water sections don't last too long. The gameplay is very satisfiying with a wide range of weapons like dynamite and a tommygun but can also get a bit unorthodox like a voodoo doll(my fav) or tesla gun. Most of these weapons also have alt fire modes, varying up how you can approch enemies. And rounding it all out is defensive items like medkits and boots to help you jump higher and a few others. There's also plenty of replay value with many secrets, references to horror films, and hidden levels. 

The expansion pack was every bit as good as the main game. It wasn't just more levels, this added new ideas for level layouts and while you don't get new weapons or fight new enemies, it had some of the best levels due to cool puzzle ideas and new ways they used them. If it was an episode on the main game it would probably be my favorite despite how much I enjoyed the others. While this won't effect my review I should point out that the modding community is alive and well with some talented users that make great content. So if you enjoy using mods then this one has that in spades.

Overall with it's creepy atmosphere, satisfying gameplay, great replay value, and large amount of content(even without mods) this was one of the best FPS's i've played on steam.

One of the best FPS games I have ever played!  If you are a fan of other Build engine games like Duke Nukem 3D (or retro FPS shooters in general), then there is a very good chance that you will enjoy this game as well!

The story is pretty simple (but probably more interesting than the average FPS story)... it's about a 19th century gunslinger named Caleb who, with his girlfriend, joins an evil cult known as the Cabal.  Caleb and his girlfriend wind up reaching the highest ranks of the Cabal and become part of the elite group called “The Chosen.”  However, the sinister god that the cult worships, Tchernobog, decides to kill Caleb and the rest of “The Chosen" members.  A few decades later, Caleb rises from his grave and exclaims, “I live... Again!” (one of several references to the classic Army of Darkness film).  From that point on, all Caleb cares about is seeking revenge on the dark god for betraying his followers, and Caleb is not hesitant on annihilating anything that crosses his path (whether it's harmless civilians or Tchernobog's army of evil creatures / armed cultists).

Aside from Army of Darkness, there are a plethora of movie, book and song references to be found!  A reference to The Crow film can be found near the very beginning of the game (the main character in that film is murdered, but he later resurrects from his grave and wants revenge on his killers).  Most of the other references are based on horror films... a few obvious examples include The Shining, Friday the 13th, Dawn of the Dead, Nightmare on Elm Street etc.  E2M4 (which is heavily based on one of the films mentioned above) is one of my favorite levels!

The level design in this game is really top-notch stuff!  In my opinion, this game easily has the best atmosphere out of Duke 3D and Shadow Warrior.  Mixed with creepy music, many of the levels are very macabre in nature, and the levels are varied.  You will need to shed blood in places like a funeral, moving train, carnival, ancient temple, lumber mill, hospital and many other cool locations.

The most important thing in any FPS game is the gunplay, and the gunplay in Blood is extremely fun.  For one, the game has one of my favorite weapon sets in any FPS game!  How many games have things like a flare gun, spray can that acts as a flamethrower, three different types of dynamite, and magical weapons like a voodoo doll?!  There are a variety of ways to kill each enemy, and each weapon has its use.  Most of the weapons also have an alternate fire mode (not a very common feature among 90s FPS shooters), adding to the weapons versatility.

And as you can expect from a game called Blood, there is a lot of blood and gore in this game, and it is a lot darker than Duke 3D.  So for you gorehounds, there is plenty of it to be seen in this game.  Caleb takes pleasure in watching his enemies scream in agony as they are being burnt to death, and Caleb will often laugh with a sadistic tone when he blows enemies up into bloody smithereens.  Nothing is more fun than entering a room filled with zombies and obliterating them all with dynamite or the Napalm launcher!

The game is pretty challenging too if you play on Lightly Broiled (skill 3) difficulty, and extremely tough on Extra Crispy (skill 5) difficulty. For me personally, Lightly Broiled is the funnest difficulty to play on.  It's not easy, but it's also not too hard either.  There are a good amount of enemies to destroy, the enemies don't deal an insane amount of damage to you, and the enemies don't feel like bullet sponges (unlike on Extra Crispy).  If you are up for the major challenge and want to complete the game on Extra Crispy, I would recommend completing the game on an easier difficulty and learning where most of the secrets are located beforehand.

There are also some pretty cool power-ups, such as Reflective Shots (deflects melee / firearm attacks onto the attacker) and Guns Akimbo (gives you the ability to dual wield certain weapons).
 Some very useful items in the game include the Boots of Jumping, which are extremely overpowered.  I am not sure if this was intended by the developers, but the Boots of Jumping not only gives you the ability to jump higher, but turning them on also makes you immune to fall damage and crush damage (in other words, you can't die from a crusher nor from a long fall when they are enabled).  They also refill to 100 after completing a level.  Pretty cool stuff.

So in conclusion, if you are a fan of the horror genre and 90s FPS shooters, then you should definitely give this game a try (and be sure to give the source port called BloodGDX a try).  I don't think this will happen, but here is to hoping that a new Blood game comes out.  If we can get new games for Duke Nukem, Doom, Shadow Warrior, Rise of the Triad etc., then there is no reason why we shouldn't get a new Blood game.

Blood es el tercero que conforma el trío dinamico del [b] Build Engine [/b].

Es un juego desarrollado por Monolith en 1997, posee una atmosfera sombría y oscura, como también un estilo sangriento "over the top".

La jugabilidad es como la de cualquier juego del Build Engine, excepto que en este existen más de 3 llaves y el arsenal es muy diferente como de los Duke Nukem 3D y Shadow Warrior. Además que el nivel de dificultad no es igual a los 2 juegos antés mencionado, dependiendo de que dificultad estés; habran más enemigos y tendrán más vida como también la capacidad de hacer más daño.

El diseño de niveles es buenismo, no es de sorprender en juegos de Build Engine, ya que todos tienen un diseño urbano pseudo-realista con algo de interactividad en ellos.

Pueden obtener este juego también en GOG junto con algunos "goodies", y mejor optimizado, ya que está versión públicada en Steam es una versión del instalador de GOG. Pero no es malo, pero es más sugerible jugar con el de GOG.

Lastimosamente este juego jamás tuvo un lanzamiento en su código fuente (Source Code), por lo que no hubo ningúna clase de Source Port hasta recientemente en este año. BloodGDX es un Source port hecho con ingeniería-inversa, por lo que pueden jugarlo en mayores resoluciones y mejor compatiblidad en OS modernos sin necesidad de Dosbox.

32556434.review:
Blood is without a doubt a timeless classic, and one of the best and most challenging FPS games of all time, but sadly hasn't had the support it deserves, with this Steam version being a good example of this, just being a stock standard DosBox upload. 

You take on the role of Caleb, a great shot, fast runner and strong swimmer. He's also the now ex leader of an evil cult known as the Cabal. After the dark god (who you worshiped) Tchernabog kills all of your friends, and you, you awaken from your grave seeking revenge. Revenge that can only be paid in blood! Caleb is the definition of an anti hero. He's a bad guy only out for revenge, not to save anyone.

If you've ever Shadowed some Warriors, Duked some Nukems or Doomed some twos you'll know what to expect. This is a product of it's time, so expect to get lost in vast sprawling levels, collecting keys, finding secrets and gettinggunned down by surprise monster closets. The locations you'll visit are some of the most varied you'll find in an FPS game, with detailed textures, sprites and interactive items, many being unique to each level. The locations feel believable in a strange way. You've never been to any place like them, but you just know places like it exist. Most of the levels are heavily inspired by of era horror movies, and the tone often aligned with Evil Dead. You'll visit abandoned towns, train stations, carnivals, cathedrals, hotels, forrests, it really would take too long to list them all. Each level feels more or less connected, with you starting off where the previous level left off, adding to the continuous feel of your journey.

 This game is hard, and I mean get out hard. If you think you're an FPS expert, play Blood on well done, then we'll talk. Quicksaving is your best friend here, the levels are long, and if you don't know what you're doing you'll die, a lot. Is the challenge legitimate? Yes. If you know how to manage your resources and know how the enemies behave, you can get through this game start to finish on Lightly Broiled, which I STRONGLY suggest for a first playthrough. Once that's down, you have Well Done, and boy am I thankfull for that setting. It's like the middle ground between normal and get out hard, like right in the middle of Doom's Ultra Violence and Nightmare. If it weren't for Well Done, the game would be much less fun casually for multiple playthroughs.

Blood packs some of the best weapons I've ever had the pleasure of using in an FPS game, and that's saying something. From tommy guns, to vodoo dolls all the way up to a napalm launcher, this game has weapons you won't forget. Each weapon serves a purpose, and that's killing whatever abomination in your way. The enemy roster in this game gives Doom two a run for its money. The sprite work is absolutely phenomenal, and breaths life into each enemy you face, not to mention the fantastic voice work by Stephan Weyte, who gives Caleb a real presence with his likeable attitude and off colour humer. The music is also a treat, with a full 13 track midi soundtrack. Each song fits each level accordingly, with chants, wispers and catchy tunes midi tunes.

TLDR, the game is fast, fun, challenging, great to look at and listen to, and oozing with creativity. You should buy it, it's FIVE DOLLARS which is highway robbery, even when it's not on a sale. Just a little bit of set up will be needed to get the game running properly, and if you need any help with that just comment and i'll try to lead you in the right direction. Truely a timeless classic.

'Blood' is absolutely one of my all-time favorite games. 

While it is essentially a 'Doom' clone, 'Blood' carries it's own twisted charms in that the story makes little to no sense (unless you know your Horror films/fiction) and because of the sheer volume and variety in it's content. Yes. I see you all rolling your eyes and telling me that it is mostly running around shooting anything that moves, and that is true. However, there truly is SO much to love about this game. 

Lacking the misogyny of 'Duke Nukem 3D' and the veiled racial stereotyping of 'Shadow Warrior', 'Blood' instead plays firmly up to it's cliched B-Movie roots. Players find themselves thrust into a Lovecraftian dystopia, choc-full of homicidal cultists, ghouls and mimes (yes, I said mimes...what? They're annoying...at least in this game) as the game's maniacal undead protagonist Caleb sates his veracious lust for revenge against those who've wronged him. Another great aspect of 'Blood' is the choice of weapons on offer which range from the relatively mundane to the downright cruel. Personal favorites include Caleb's starting weapon - a rather nasty pitch fork that he most likely brought back with him from Hell - and a voodoo poppet capable of reducing even the most resilient foe to dust.  

If there are any down sides to 'Blood' it's that while the game has some considerable length to it, it is recommended that the game not be played in a single sitting. The game's soundtrack is suitably apt for the subject matter but 6+ hours of listening to foreboding synths and children chanting pseudo-Satanic mantras does tend to prove detrimental to one's overall mood - and I've been a Metalhead for 17 years so I'm used to this sort of thing. Also worth noting is that like it's biggest inspiration, Sam Raimi's 'The Evil Dead', 'Blood' is NOT child friendly. Like many games from the irreverent 1990s, developer Monolith designed 'Blood' as a game for adults and as such the young-uns need to be kept clear of this title. You wouldn't let your kids play 'Doom' or 'Carmageddon' would you? Well, the same goes for this game as well.  

In summary, if you're a conservative you'll hate 'Blood'. If you're a fan of revisionist post-modern Horror gaming, you'll love it.

31633058.review:
Do not believe the amount of hours played on this game. Trust me, I've played this back when it first released long ago, and I still remember where most of the secrets, though I forgot how excrutiating and difficult this game can be, and the death count can rise higher than even Dark Souls or Super Meat Boy.

How can a more-than-a-decade-old game compare in difficulty to modern games like Dark Souls? Let me explain.

This game's challenge comes with the selection of difficulty mode, but the maps and monster dynamics as well as numbers change. Consider the 'easiest' difficulty to be the first time you play through Dark Souls, and conside the hardest difficulty (Extra Crispy) to be New Game +4. Monsters are more numerous, more dangerous, and come with more surprises that are worse than the last. Only difference is there's not RPG gear elements here; only your wits, your guns, and the strange menegerie of cult artifacts you use to destroy the minions of The One That Binds.

You play as Caleb, a ressurrected foul mouth cowboy ex-cultist hellbent on avenging the betrayal done to you by the Dreaming God. Each episode introduces new sets of monsters, weapons, and challenges, each level designed rather meticulously and advanced for it's time, much like the memorable maps of Doom 2. 

The weapons are some of my favorite and memorable ones from any game (from the simple sawed off shotgun and dynamite bundle to the more cult saavy Voodoo Dolls and the all-powerful Life Leech staff). Nothing satisfied me more than the Napalm Launcher and even the Can of Hairspray. Each weapon has an alternate attack mode, with the Sawed Off merely firing both barrels of the gun at once while the Can of Hairspray changes from a simple homemade flamethrower (lighter included) into a molotov cocktail that can clear a whole room.

The maps are loaded with all sorts of traps, ambushes, close calls, and unfairness. You'll find out quickly which maps you like and loathe, but each of them always have a good bit of dark humor mixed in with the fear of every corner hiding Tommy-gun wielding, dynamite-hurling cultists ready to put you back in the dirt from where you came. 

For the things I glorify, the game engine itself is clunky and sometimes rage inducing, much like Dark Souls. It takes time to figure out how the dynamite bundles toss and mouse-aiming has not been improved too thoroughly. Some of the weapons like the Flaregun have issues with connecting properly when firing at steeper angles other than horizontal (the game relies more on the autoaim and assumes you are using keyboard only). The amount of times I've killed myself due to tossing a bundle of dynamite into an invisible wall thinking it would make it over or it strikes a panicking human that runs in front of my toss and sends both of us back to hell. All I can say is Save. Save. Save.

I have quite a bit of nostalgia for this game, along with Doom and Duke Nukem 3d, and while I wish the core engine and mechanics where implemented better (the Cursed Doll alternate fire works like a giant room clear but seems broken and uses the ammo while only killing 1 enemy), the maps and the atmosphere are memorable as well as the gravelly sarcastic one liners the MC dolls out while setting zombies and cultists on fire brings out the sadistic glee from wiping evil from the face of the earth, and I don't just mean the mimes.

Addendum: If ever you see a hand creature crawling towards you, KILL IT FAST OR RUN. If it touches you, it will choke you to death. Mashing USE key can pull it off (may not in some cases), but you'll probably die before you do. This game is harsh, unforgiving, and these fuckers literally choke you to death at the WORST POSSIBLE FUCKING MOMENT. Worst handjob ever.

"I hate mimes." - Caleb

30182058.review:
[h1]"I live... again!"[/h1]
[i]- Caleb quoting Army of Darkness[/i]

You probably shouldn't buy this game. 

Blood: One Unit Whole Blood is not a true port. Or even a "fake" port. It's just a DOSbox frontend thrown up on Steam. So it's buggy, runs like grenade thrown under a truck, crashes if you sneeze, music doesn't loop, game has trouble registering what you're shooting at if you're on a sloped surface, that sort of thing. List goes on for a while.

But I'm going to recommend this anyway. I shouldn't, and I do reiterate that you shouldn't buy it because DOSbox, but I'm going to.

BLOOD is a fantastic game.

I'm always waiting for the tipping point in a game. The point where it just gives up - levels get boring and reuse assets like their life depends on it, enemy placement gets lazy with open arenas filled with them or corridors sprinkled with them, and you just sort of struggle your way through content that really isn't worth playing. 

That moment never came for BLOOD. It does the fantastical, the impossible, and manages to keep levels well-paced, interesting and novel right up until the credits roll (for the fourth time). That's such a rare occurence it's practically mythic. 

There's bad levels, of course there are, but they're sour picks in a bunch and even they try their best to inject novelty.

[h1]"Th-th-th-that's all folks!"[/h1]
[i]- Caleb quoting the Looney Tunes[/i]

With SFX and alt-fires to spare, just about every weapon in BLOOD feels amazing to use, splattering enemy entrails across the wall more so. The amount of physics wizardry, enemy corpses and general bullet hole/blood splatter/bullet casing sprite longevity is insane, and adds even more weight to shooting up the novel environs.

Keeping you accompanied in all this is fantastic core mechanics that sees you flying around arenas combining crouching and jumping while strafing at mach speed to take on hordes of lethal cultists, dogs, more cultists, fishmen, some more cultists, and the same 2 minibosses thrown at you constantly!

Alright, yeah, BLOOD has a real problem with enemy variety. 

You have a select few mooks, and honestly the boring cultists and zombies are the only ones fun to fight. The rest have weird hitboxes or periods of invulnerability that just make it a bit of a chore. Or a flame-breath attack that's basically just free damage if they blindside you.

The expansion episode included in this, Plasma Pak's "Post Mortem", attempts to fix this by adding some recoloured cultist sprites and such. It doesn't really work, and that threshold of lazy design happens to Post Mortem in about 12 seconds.

[h1]"What are you gonna do? Bleed on me?"[/h1]
[i]- Caleb quoting Monty Python and the Holy Grail[/i]

Post Mortem does add a totally new boss type, but that doesn't really make up for just making copy pasted rooms and filling them full of mooks to grind at like every mediocre WAD you've ever played. And Plasma Pak's Post-Mortem is the inhouse one, Cryptic Passage just gives up before it starts.

There's a few bosses to break up the action, but they're mostly just big mooks that kill you in two hits. Everything in this game already hits ridiculously hard, not sure that was necessary, but they serve as a memorable encounter if nothing else.

Apart from the intensely mediocre expansion episode, the most damning thing you can say about it is that it's filled to the brim with pop-culture references. Now this wasn't an isolated problem, and some people even like it, but I just found it disheartening to find that every single memorable line, use of wit or humour, or even entire levels were just pop-culture carryovers. 

Not one decent original line. Bit ridiculous.

[h1]"Are you gonna bark all day little doggy, or are you gonna bite?"[/h1]
[i]- Caleb quoting Resevoir Dogs[/i]

So that's Blood. Worth playing? Absolutely. Worth buying? Probably not. 

But if you decide to put up with DOS Box anyway, here's easily one of the best shooters ever made. Just not in the best presentation ever made.

[h1]There's a lot of great DoS shooters out there, Blood is without a doubt my favorite.[/h1]

Blood is one of the first games to have alternate firing modes with a variety of weapons that compliment each other in the heat of combat. The standard pistol is replaced by a flare gun, any enemy you shoot will get a firery glob stuck to their body slowly enveloping them in flames. They're still actively hunting you down, scenarios like this will force you to be constantly moving, most games depend on corner shooting but the combination of oddball firearms are one of the main contenders to why blood stands out as a FPS.

You end up micromanaging weapons, these guns aren't just bullet sprayers. I'll be damned if this game doesn't have the most satisfying grenade throw in any game out there, lighting a stick of dynamite that explodes on impact. Throwing it in a precise ark against the motley cast of cultists never seems to get old.

The five chapters include mastercrafted levels that feel open-ended due to clever design, multiple hidden easter eggs in each level with refrences to popular horror tropes rewards the player for exploring the level in a way most games take for granted.

When you think about the limited amount of tools the developers had at the time it makes me gobsmacked that they somehow still managed to make some tense atmospheric levels for the time being. Even the old textures that have a limited color palette still hold up because of the deliberate color choice the developers took.

I find it hard to have any negative things to say about Blood, the cutscenes have always been a complete joke, but they appear so infrequently at the start and end of a complete chapter that they never detract from the overall feeling. 

This is a great game to pop open just to have some fast chaotic fun. Blood still holds up, so even if you don't belong in the category of DoS enthusiast, this game is well worth your time.

28417415.review:
Before I start this review, I would like to mention the quality of this port, or lack thereof. Blood is confugured to run in Dosbox, and is configured like crap. There is a way to fix it, thanks to [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=286998267] This Awesome Guide [/url]
Now on to the main review.
People well versed in the FPS genre will always talk about the Build Engine Trinity games. Those games being Duke Nukem 3D, Shadow Warrior, and Blood. I have completed Duke 3D, and the Life's A Beach expansion pak, while also playing a good chunk of Shadow Warrior's campaign. Even though I like these two games, the both suffer from severe problems which hinders them from being put in a pedestal next to other FPS classics like Doom 2 or Unreal. Based off my experiences with those two games, I expected Blood to follow in a similar vain. I haven't been this pleased to be wrong about prior thoughts to a game since Doom 2016 (which I thought would suck, but is awesome).
Once you configure Blood to your liking, you are then taken to the game's menu screen, where you are able to select the episode, and the difficulty. In Blood you play as Caleb, a guy in a trenchcoat with a fedora, who is seeking vengance after his master betrays him, by burrying him alive. Afterwords you wake up from your grave, to then quote a line from Army of Darkness. Blood stands out from the other Build Engine games for 2 reasons.
1) The atmosphere in Blood is creepy and unsetteling at times, engrosing you in it's world that has been carefully constructed. Notable levels include the Dark Carnaval in Episode 1, a good chunk of Episode 2, and a Forest level in Episode 4. In comparison, Duke 3D and Shadow Warrior lack any sense of atmosphere, as focus was put on other elements. 
2) Blood has a unique weapon lineup. Starting with a Pitchfork and Flare Gun, up to more devestating weapons like the Napalm Launcher, and Tesla Rifle. These weapons do an exelent job at dispatching Caleb's foes.
Speaking of which, the enemy design in Blood fits the theme like a glove. From Zombies and Robed Cultists, to Sea Monsters and Hellhounds, Blood's enemy roster is unique in both appearance and functionality. This only slightly let down by the fact that the flying enemy types suffer from poor A.I. at times. Gargoyles in particular have a hard time doing anything usefull in big open areas, and will just fuck around in the air, being a general nusance. Episode 3 also suffers a bit from mazelike level design, and forgetable backdrops, and is easily the most forgettable episode in the game. Other than those complaints, Blood is an amazing experience. This is without mentioning the hidden secrets, the refrences Caleb makes, the awesome powerups, the extreme usage of blood and gore, and cool but not too challenging boss fights.
Blood also had two expansion packs released for it as well. The Plasma Pak was an official expansion by Monolith, and upgrades the main game to Blood With Plasma. This pack adds a new episode, multiple new enemy types, and a new boss. It's fun, and is a good test of raw skill for those well versed in older FPS games. Later released was the Cryptic Graves expansion pak, released by Wizzard Works, who also released a lot of Duke Nukem 3D expansion Paks. Cryptic Graves is a pretty good expansion pak, with memorable locations, and fun level design, that only falls short of being pretty easy. Both these expansion packs are included with this purchase, so this is the definitive version of the game to get at the moment, only short of a full HD source port. Blood is now one of my favorite FPS games, and is my favorite game of the Build Engine Trinity. I highly reccomend that anyone who is a fan of FPS games pick this one up, as it lives up to its name in every regard. I'll end this review by quoting Caleb quoting Army of Darkness.
"I Live, Again..."

28397749.review:
Blood is a first person shooter that came out in the busy PC game market of 1997 and runs on a modified BUILD engine, the same engine that powered Duke Nukem 3D a year prior. While Duke3D was developed by 3D Realms Blood was being made by Q Studios, an independent dev funded by 3D Realms and originally by the working title 'Horror 3D'. Scheduled for release in early '97 Q Studios was acquired by Monolith Productions in late '96 and a press release not long after announced all the rights being sold to Monolith so 3D Realms could focus their efforts on Shadow Warrior, another FPS using a more advanced version of the BUILD engine, slated for release the same year. Where Duke3D paid homage to 80's and 90's action films and Shadow Warrior being an Oriental flavor of the same game, Blood would take its inspiration from horror films instead.

The story in Blood is more fleshed out than other BUILD games, beginning with the legendary and ruthless gunslinger known as Caleb, the protagonist and effectively anti-hero of Blood. Born in Texas, he worked up his merciless reputation at the young age of seventeen in the late 1800's. One day Caleb discovered a woman named Ophelia, who had her homestead burnt to the ground by the Cabal after her husband tried to rescind, killing him and her young son in the process. Enraged and heartbroken, not at the Cabal, but blaming her spouse's foolish actions for the death of her child. Caleb being perplexed but intrigued would take the woman in and nurse her back to health. She would later become his lover, and the gateway to the underworld of the Cabal, a cult who worshipped the dark god Tchernobog, The One That Binds, aptly named for his binding of the realities in the known universe.

Tchernobog's true age and origin are unknown, his original body having been destroyed long ago, forcing him to take control of another in order to fulfill his duties, thus the Cabal was born. He is a morally ambiguous entity who underwent numerous incarnations over the course of his existence. The earliest known was that of a Buddhist high priest, converting the Cabal into a religious regiment, practicing docile rituals of penance and self-control. But his latest incarnation was colored by that of a bitter and hateful man, who bent the Cabal towards the dark goal of world domination, acting as Tchernobog's personal army on earth. Tchernobog is now a more active force in the world, discarding the position of the Cabal leader in favor of direct influence over the cult himself, giving orders from his throne in the Hall of Epiphany. He would however select four in his ranks to become The Chosen, with Caleb and Ophelia being part of it, with the others being Ishmael and Gabriel. The Chosen were the Cabal's elite servants, as well as the highest generals in Tchernobog's army. Caleb was designated to be the leader of The Chosen, and to be selected as the next incarnation of Tchernobog himself if the need or opportunity ever arised.

But for reasons unknown Tchernobog had deemed his Chosen as failures, casting them down and leaving their ill-fated destinies to Cheogh, ruler of gargoyles, Shial, mother of spiders, and Cerberus, a massive two-headed dog, who act as generals for Tchernobog's otherworldly army. Whereas the other Chosen were taken away by monsters, Caleb was confined into the tomb of a hallowed grave instead. Not content with staying dead, Caleb would rise again, in a body he no longer knows, and in a world he has grown to despise in the year 1928. Being a sarcastic man with a strong bent towards sadism, and with the love of his life being taken from him, his journey will be a bloody and vengeance-filled war against the Cabal, while hoping to learn the reason for his exile and seeking out the other Chosen, for with their combined power and strength can he hope to take on Tchernobog.

Blood lives up to it's namesake, it's easily the bloodiest FPS in 1997. Enemies die in several violent ways, with zombies being decapitated and the player able to kick around their severed heads, to cultists and other humanoid enemies being set on fire and burning alive while they cry out in pain. Most outcomes result with over-the-top red showers and gibs galore that litter the ground, making Duke3D and even SW look tame by comparison. There's also other unique deaths that can be triggered with specific weapon types. Viscera aside there is also several enemies with their own special resistances and weaknesses to certain damage properties which you will have to learn in order to master combat.

Gameplay is traditional for the era, in which you roam some thirty-odd levels, key-hunting and killing everything that gets in your way, all contained within the game's five episodes (six if you count the add-on Cryptic Passage). But like other BUILD engine titles what seperates Blood from the-then common Doom clone is the level of interactivity, realism and various gags in the game's levels. There is a host of pop culture references and easter eggs of the era that are still delightful to discover to this day and the maps all ooze with atmosphere and small details, with even the horror elements more fun than frightening.

To make your life miserable there is a large and varied bestiary of semi-humans, ghouls and other things that go bump in the night that stay true to the game's themes. From nuisance enemies like rats and spiders, to the common and crazed yapping cultists and axe-wielding zombies, as well as more otherworldly horrors like gargoyles in flesh and stone variants, ghostly phantasms, fire-breathing hellhounds, and oddities like the severed hands that have a personality all on their own while trying to choke the life out of you. They all hit hard, making battles with them deadly, especially the cultists who are the sole hitscanners, capable of lopping dynamite in your direction, definitely making them high priority to dispose of ASAP.

But you too wield a large and powerful arsenal of your own to fight back with. Starting with only a pitchfork, unconventional for the genre, but quickly work up to a flare gun in place of a traditional pea shooter, a double barreled sawed off shotgun, gangster style tommy gun, the explosive and highly flammable napalm launcher in place of a rocket launcher, several types of dynamite, some of which can be remote detonated, improvised flamethrower in the form of an aerosol can, to the almost anachronistic tesla cannon and even the dark arts with the voodoo doll and life leech. All firearms can be dual-wielded with a power-up called Guns Akimbo and most weapons possess an alternate firing mode, revolutionary for the time. Other pickups come in traditional and non-traditional flavors, you can heal via a portable medikit or from the life essence of fallen foes in the form of a still-beating heart, and there is armor types tailored to absorbing specific kinds of damage. Better yet is power-ups to make you completely undetectable or invincible for a short duration.

Visually the game is on par with Duke3D or SW and has faux 3D elements in the engine like room-over-room and voxels for things like weapon pickups and certain decorative objects. While it lacked the true 3D technology of Quake II that year Blood's personality made the game far more charming than its competitors that overshadowed it. Sound design is loud and satisfying, and the soundtrack comes in midi and CD audio form, with both being equally great to listen to.

Criticisms allude to the lack of polish, most notable in Blood compared to other BUILD games, with bizarre enemy behavior, weird hitboxes and collision detection, and some bad exploits like crouch and physics abuse, the bosses are far too easy to kill and the instant-reaction from cultist attacks paired with the high damage output can lead to some unfair moments.

Blood is still bloody good fun however and thus comes as highly recommended to fans of the genre and the BUILD engine in general. Spill some.

4.0/5

28357446.review:
I rate the game Blood: One Unit Whole Blood 3.5/5. Pretty good.

Despite the fact that this is now an extremely old FPS (first person shooter) game from the same family of games as Duke Nukem 3D (using the same game engine as the original Shadow Warrior and Duke Nukem 3D), this is still fairly fun to play, despite how ugly looking its graphics are. In fact, as this version is probably far more stable than the original version of the game, being far less prone to crashes and freeze-ups, this version may be even better than the original ever was. There are some drawbacks however, the worst of which is the game's inability to have its resolution increased beyond a lowly 800 by 600 pixels.

+Good and responsive controls for mouse/keyboard though the now antiquated manual method of pressing buttons to look up and down remains clumsy in the extreme. If you remember, this was always clumsy and was not remedied until the advent of the first Quake game and the general adoption of the control style used therein.

+Still an exciting game to play with lots of action.

+This game is extremely inexpensive and gives you at least 10 hours of gameplay on the easiest difficulty level. The gameplay consists mostly of finding keys to unlock doors into yet another area, one level after another but the maze-like level design is well made with lots of intricate puzzles and clever references to movies and books throughout. As an added benefit, this game should work on pretty much any computer which now exists and can run dos box.

+Good, highly atmospheric, interesting and creepy music. This game features the same music which was on the CD (compact disc) version of the game way back when it first game out.

+Not very many bugs (asides from certain non-essential menu options not doing what they claim to do but instead having no effect whatsoever). While it was normal for the original version of Blood to freeze up totally back when it first came out, this version is very, very stable and runs fast.

+/-The sound is often fairly good, the screams of characters (especially when certain ones are set on fire) are pretty detailed. That said, many of the sound effects can seem tinny and as the exact same sound effects are repeated over and over (like they were in the old days) the sound can seem boring. The nifty things your character says to himself (in a fairly Duke Nukem sort of way, but with a very different personality) does help spice things up however.

+/-The blood and gore in this game, or at least its depiction of it, may seem tame by comparison to today's higher resolution, more detailed games. Still, the amount of gore seems fairly realistic thus adding a bit of grittiness to an otherwise cartoon-like atmosphere.

+/-It is very easy to save your game anywhere. However there are NO autosaves and it is also easy to potentially save your game so that you may end up reloading your game into a totally impossible-to-survive situation.

-The graphics have not aged well and the maximum resolution which this game actually let me set it to, a lowly 800x600 seems dismally low and textures and characters alike seem terribly ugly and primitive looking. Games with throwback/retro graphics like Minecraft look better by comparison. The game has options for higher resolutions but the game does not let you actually select these resolutions making for some potentially frustrating menu interactions. The game's animation is, I think, not anymore jerky than it originally was. The graphics for Blood were intended to be played on an CRT (cathode ray tube) monitor which featured extreme contrast versus brightness ratios. This means that the textures and everything else in this game are intended for an entirely different type of computer imaging and lighting technology. A technology where the pixels of the screen themselves glow with their own light (not with any back lighting). The textures, on any newer LCD (liquid crystal display) or other new technology monitors will look too bright, the colors will not be as intense and indeed, the entire game will seem somehow faded like old parchment and the deep blacks will instead merely be gray. There is no way to decrease the game's brightness below a certain point (which is what would be required to make this game look as it was intended). You might try, if you really care more about this game than I do, to further increase your current generation monitor's contrast ratio even further, for on the old CRT screens, pretty much anywhere that was not fairly well lit, was completely dark.

Blood has to be one of my favorite games ever, period. It is the one game I always come back to.

So, why am I then not recommending it? Easy: this game did not age well. If you did play the game before, you already know how awesome it is and you don't need this review. But if you are the target audience of this review - someone who hasn't played it yet and whose vision is not clouded by nostalgia - I can imagine you will have a hard time to get into it.

Even at release the graphics were dated, everything being drowned in blurry brown and grey pixels. This release has literally zero Steam-integration and just runs in Dosbox, with a fairly minimal resoluton and pretty disappointing framerate. I know that gameplay triumphs graphics, but this Blood really looks and feels outdated.

The controls are very oldschool and you will have to use external programs if you want decent mouse + keyboard. Again, those who did play it when it came out decades ago will have no problems with only arrow-keys or, if you are a bit younger, wasd-control, but otherwise jumping into this FPS unprepared will be quite disappointing.

You know what, this release literally looks worse than it did at day of release, more than 20 years ago. You were once able to run it in VESA mode (1024 and beyond resolutions), but the Steam version does run any higher than 800x600.

Now, scroll up. Seriously scroll up: one of the top reviews on Steam today is a negative one, questioning how to change controls. Answer me this: do YOU, potential buyer, know how to change the control scheme of a DOS game? Those who payed this in the nineties will know, but does someone who has never touched it before?

If you know of yourself that you are able to appreciate ancient games with ancient looks and ancient controls, then you in for quite a treat. Gameplay is fast and fun. You remember that? Straightforward, undilluted fun? Pure FPS goodness in a 1930-ies horror world, with so many winks to horror movies that it will make your head sping. The weapons feel great, the humour is on the mark, the sounds and music breathe atmosphere and level-layout in general is fantasic.

Oh God the level design, no other game ever came close to it ... just thinking about it makes me want to load up Blood again! Of course the story is rubbish, but if you really expected better from a 1996 FPS then you are probably in the wrong place kid.

So, I repeat: this game is a marvel. But if you don't already know that, the chance that you will ever come to agree with me is small. The barrier for a new player has become just too large to overcome and this will end up being another "classic" game in your steam folder that you simply never come to actually playing.

26485792.review:
A complete repackaging of the classic 1997 Build Engine FPS.

If you've already played Blood, you know what to expect. 

For those who have never played Blood, it is a run-and-gun shooter in the same vein as Duke Nukem and Doom, but focuses much more on gothic/occult horror more so than sci-fi elements. Out of the three shooters it tends to have the largest and most maze-like levels, although some of them are guilty of padding (there is a lot of 'use Key A to open a room where Key B is literally just sitting on a desk') and lots of backtracking.

All of the weapons feel pretty powerful and the enemies are fun to kill, especially the Cultists. Expect to see a lot of blood, gore and graphic imagery, it lives up to the game title!

I feel it is important to note that this is NOT a modern port - it is literally the original DOS version running in a DOSBox emulator. All of the polish and niceties that come with programs like GZDoom and eDuke32 are absent; you'll have to edit the config files in the game folder for things such as setting your key bindings or mouse sensitivity. The performance and mouse-support is decent, but definitely lacks fluidity.

This is an excellent game but I can't but help want to see it with OpenGL dynamic lighting, modern resolution support, and other doodads that are now standard in Doom and Duke3D; hopefully we will finally see a source port (official or unofficial) someday.

26428365.review:
Blood might not be revolutionary like Doom, but holy hell is it fun. Varied enemies, awesome weapons, dark humor, and an early 20th century horror theme make this game stand out from the crowd. There's never been a game quite like it since. 

However, both the Steam and GOG versions do not run on an updated port of the Build engine - but rather use Dosbox to emulate the game. Lots of hoops need to be jumped through in order to make Blood even playable on modern machines, but thankfully there is a very helpful guide by MrEWhite that tells you everything you need to do to get it running. Regardless, it's a shame that this is even necessary. Warner Brothers owns the rights to Blood, and they're unwilling to part with them for fair price - even though it's highly unlikely they'll even -do- something with the license. A source port will probably never happen, and that's a damn shame.

Still, it's a great game that every fan of classic shooters should experience.

26403647.review:
There's a reason this is one of the big three.  The game is fantastic.  The level design is some of the best I've seen in a long while, where the level designers utilized as much real estate as they could, having players loop around and cover the same ground a few times.  It leads to levels that can take quite a while to beat, and can sometimes be confusing, and it gets a bit old having these giant winding levels all the time.  But they are incredibly well designed and fun to go through.

The enemies are varied, as are the weapons.  And with that comes a whole lot of weapon swapping.  You'll quickly find that just trying to power through everything with your workhorse is no an efficient, or even effective, method of dealing with the hordes.  Some weapons just work better against some enemies than others.  I really like this.  It wasn't often you had games that made you actually USE the arsenal you collect through the game.

There are a couple downsides.  There's at least one level where you can block yourself off from a key and not be able to complete it without cheating or restarting.  And, as I said, the giant levels CAN cause some fatigue, and get a bit repetitive at times.  This is especially bad in the episode where three levels back to back feature frozen hedge mazes.  The game also has a few areas where they've put too many hitscanning enemies in one area that just leads to large amounts of automatic damage.

But, for the most part, this game is balanced, challenging, and fun.  Absolutely worth a try!

Cryptic Passage: Well, I had some issues with this one on Steam.  Textures were off on the third level, so I ended up playing it from my older CD copy.  Overall, this expansion has a few thematic problems, but the quality is very high.  I was in fact very impressed with it overall.  There really wasn't anything new added to the game, and the story was weak, but it served its purpose.  It's a shame you can't just choose this one natively on Steam, you have to edit the dosbox config file manually to play it, but once you do you're good to go.  I dislike a few things they did, such as using life essences as medkits - yes, the game needs medkits (and it has them via medicine pouches, as this expansion uses later on), but life essences come from the fallen enemies, thematically.  On top of that, Wizard Works didn't really seem to understand how various enemy types needed different weapons to be most effective with, and kinda through groups together than didn't mesh well that way.  in and of itself that's not a huge problem, it actually adds a bit of challenge and diversity to the game, but I think they did so a little too often.  They also kept putting the spider boss, which spawns other spiders, in small areas where she was difficult to fight.

Plasma Pak/Post Mortem: This one gave me issues with both the Steam and CD version.  Level design is still pretty good, the new cultists add some variety.  The other new enemies, however, didn't show up for me.  I mean, they were there on the maps, but there were no graphics for them, and corrupted graphics for the attacks.  And, without graphics, I was unable to actually fight them.  The literally only took damage from AOE attacks.  This made them very annoying, since I couldn't tell where they were, and couldn't fight them off.  That was a very sour note for me and gave me a more negative view of this episode than I probably otherwise would have.  Likewise, the new boss added - which I'm glad they did - I couldn't tell if it was missing attack graphics or not because it just seemed to hurt you based on being close to you.  I had no visible indication of anything else.  They also did the things I criticized Cryptic Passage for, using life essences as med kits and mixing groups of enemies.  The level design is still mostly solid, there's even one that seemed to be Hexen inspired.  I'd probably like this expansion if not for the bugs, but those bugs really put me off and not want to play it again.

Overall, the game IS still a recommendation.  Fantastic game, great enemies, great levels, great weapons, all around high quality.  Even from the unofficial expansion pack, which is usually a low point.  Worth your purchase!

You have your classic shotgun, rocket launcher, and SMG arsenal. With a few stand out weapons, the dynomite and voodoo doll. The over the top dismemberment and gore was pretty crazy for the time, and in my opinion is still pretty badass.

Sound: I had an issue where the ingame music would fail to play the next track, really I think its an issue with the port, nothing a quick google search couldn't fix. The gun sounds pack a lot of punch and the screams/maniacal laughter of the enemies and the player character are crisp and really take you back to 1997.

Graphics: It's a pre Quake '90s shooter, so it was still in the 2.5D style of the era, enemies are rendered as sprites, while ammo boxes and weapons are voxels. Overall it has a nice style and really nails the horror aesthetic it's going for.

Story: You are Caleb, a sort of cowboy/cultist that rises from the dead to seek revenge against a dark god. Pretty basic stuff. It's all pretty tongue and cheek, and is a nice homage to classic horror movies.

Conclusion: I paid five bucks for it and I would've paid twice that much after finishing it, I plan to come back to it one day. Aside from the port itself, namely the trouble with getting it running smoothly on modern operrating systems, it's pretty solid for what you pay. Blood is one of the last great shooters from the era. Геймплей представляет из себя шутер от первого лица с уровними, представляющими собой сопряжённые сектора, расположенные в практически полном 3D окружении. Вилы, сигнальный пистолет, обрез, Томпсон, напалмомет (читай: ракетомет, могущий поджигать врагов), три вида динамита, аэрозольный балончик, тобишь огнемет, пушка Теслы, посох и кукла Вуду. Где вы сейчас встретите подобный арсенал в игре от первого лица? Кроме того, что здесь много оружия, так каждое, кроме вил, имеет альтернативный режим огня.

Уровни, где происходит геноцид еще понять кого, вас или врагов, местами просто поражают. Есть уровни хоть и прикольные, но проходные, типа завода, которые все равно умудряются удивлять, а есть просто непотребно шикарные. Лично меня поразил секретный уровень шестого эпизода. Он выполнен в очень серых, тленных тонах. Он не мясной, но очень красивый, специально для него разработчики осерили (тобишь сделали серыми) некоторые текстуры. Такой серый, мрачный, берущий за живое уровень вы врядли где-то встретите. Низкий поклон левел-дизайнерам.

Одним словом, Blood обязателен к покупке. Но чтобы было проще наслаждаться игрой, советую скачать в сообществе игры лаунчер, сделать все по инструкции, и тогда вы поймете: какаой кал сегодня выпускают некоторые разработчики.

(Note: I played this game a lot more outside of Steam. Also unlike other 2.5D shooters, this is one that I didn't when I was young so there is no nostalgic feeling biassing me)

This game is the epitome of 2.5D shooters. Big, interactive levels, some of them are really really nice and atmospheric. A huge list of weapons with alternative fire modes and some quirky properties (your standard peashooter gun, isn't wat it seems at first). Gore, explosions, physics, you name it.

For first time players, it will probably feel a bit difficult (the highest dificulties are actually for co-op modes). But when you learn which weapon is the best for the current job, you'll get into the flow of the game and it's hugely satisfying.

Pro's:
- Very satisfying arsenal of weapons with alternative modes (and akimbo)
- Graphics (well yes, this isn't a DirectX 12 game, but the sprites really are top notch for games that old)
- Some of the coolest enemies to hunt down (CRUDOX CRUO!)
- Awesome, very fitting soundtrack
- Good (anti-hero) protagonist with a lot of funny lines
- Abundance of secrets and easter eggs (as it should with shooters from that era)
- A lot of gore
- Physics (kicking heads)
- Good dosbox port. I know some people state otherwise, but in my experience everything works as it should. I play WASD + mouse and after configuring my keys everything works.

Cons:
- You can't seem to turn down the music volume, which is a pain in the ass in levels with carnival music.
- While some levels are superb, a few levels feel tedious (but this is like 1%)
- 6 different keys might be a bit overboard instead of the classic 3 keys
- Story (if you care about that stuff, I didn't)
- Unsatisfying end boss

I would give it 85%: must play

About people taking exception to the Steam port. They are mostly wrong.
Steam version contains:
- movies;
- CD-Audio tracks in OGG (emulated, so no CD needed in drive);
- AWE32 + Wave Blaster emulation out-of-the-box;
- original Setup.Exe program;
- predefined DosBox configuration files that can be manually launched.

SO you actually CAN run the Setup.Exe, change the resolution to VESA 2.0 and stop yelling it is only 320x200...

[h1]A PRO-TIP: How to run *SETUP.EXE*? (Windows, default Steam folder location)[/h1]
1. Open "Run..." dialog (press windows key +R)
2. Paste the [b]whole[/b] following line into the textbox:
=====
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\One Unit Whole Blood\dosbox.exe" -conf "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\One Unit Whole Blood\dosboxBlood_setup.conf" -noconsole -c "exit"
=====
3. Click OK.
When you find your favourite configuration, back-up the BLOOD.CFG file. When Steam reverts your changes to the original, you can fix it easily then.

I hever heard about official 3DFX support for Doom II or Blood. Steam version contains original software graphics engine.
And this is the freaking ADVANTAGE, because all new-gen fan-made ports break the gameplay experience (no offence at all, you may try them with Steam game files)!  
I encountered no emulation lags on my old laptop. If you yell that game released in 1997 never gets 500FPS under emulated environmnent, you are IMO an id#ot, sir!

I don't even start talking about multiplayer mode (needs some effort to set up) and custom maps...

The only disadvantage is that there are no launch menu, but I needed to call Setup.Exe only a few times.

OVERALL: 1997/10! Would kick skeleton's head again!

There are 3 different Build Engine games that really count: Duke Nukem, Blood, Shadow Warrior. They all basically play the same in that you are a smartass with lots of interesting and bizarre weapons going level to level, massacring everything in your path and collecting keys to progress. 

Blood is the horror one of these three for sure. The game's plot is basically cult member who got screwed over by a demon is reborn and pissed off. The protagonist is just as clever and enjoyable as Lo Wang or Duke and personally my favourite of the three.

The weapons are quite fun and you really do feel like a sadist when you light up people with a flare gun and they scream like mad. It fits the protagonist's character extremely well. 

The level design is not as frustrating in regards to key hunting. I never needed a FAQ or to even look at the map though some secrets are really hard to find.

The game is quite long I feel and there are 5 difficulty levels so you don't ever rage quit because of it being too difficult.

It is packed with horror references from films and books even in the tiniest places. The protagonist is also quite witty and the voice acting is really cool. For younger gamers some of these will go over their heads since they didn't grow up reading Lovecraft or watching Phantasm for example. But as a 28 year old gamer I am constantly chuckling at the various references.

Also, it has numerous mods available.

All in all I think if you enjoy the Build Engine games then you will enjoy Blood but it is a great plus if you are an older horror fan.
